text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Russian newspapers this morning. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
KOMMERSANT DAILY
- First Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly Chubais says the government will be tough and the State Duma has to approve the draft law on taxes during the next three weeks before its summer recess.

- The stabilty of Russia's tea market is guaranteed for the companies involved in home production as well as in importing packaged tea, says the paper in connection with the increase of import duties on packaged tea since June 1.
- Russia's biggest car producer, AvtoVAZ, will increase payments to the state budget and will postpone a decision on splitting into two companies.
- The State Property Committee expects to earn about 11.5 trillion roubles from auctions of shares in state-owned companies.
- The fate of the results of the auction of 51 percent of Sibneft shares will be decided in the court.
- Russian government revenues will suffer because Kazakhstan has slashed import duties on vehicles, which will encourage Russians to import cars via Kazakhstan.
- The paper publishes its rating list of Russia's mutual funds.
SEVODNYA
- Russia will auction municipal-regional bonds to cover budget debts of the agrarian sector.
- Surgutneftegaz, Russia's third biggest oil producer, will encourage Russian investors.
NEZAVISIMAYA GAZETA
- YUKOS, the biggest private oil producer, plans to issue bonds to cover its budget debts.
- The government is likely to approve a number of tough measures to improve collection of alcohol excise duties.
- Russian-Ukrainian accord will obviously be ratified by both parliaments despite strong criticism.
SOVIETSKAYA ROSSIYA
- Stunning victory of left forces in France is symbolic.
KOMSOMOLSKAYA PRAVDA
- Russian soldiers will not watch movies about Rambo any more as part of a number of tough measures introduced in the army after a Russian peacekeeper shot dead of his comrades in Georgia on Monday.
MOSKOVSKY KOMSOMOLETS
- The paper accuses First Deputy Prime Minister Boris Nemtsov of manipulating with his apartments.
- President Boris Yeltsin is likely to sign in June a decree on toughening state control over reforms in the army.
Tatyana Ustinova, Moscow Newsroom, +7095 941 8520.
